Home → Recommendations & reviews → Reviews

Reviews

Read staff and customer reviews of books and reserve to collect from your library, or download to your device.

The Cleaner of Chartres by Salley Vickers

Written by The Borrowers Book Group · Published Jan 5, 2017

The Borrowers book group found The Cleaner of Chartres 'a delightful read'

Burial Rites by Hannah Kent

Written by The Borrowers Book Group · Published Jan 3, 2017

The Borrowers book group found Burial Rites 'beautifully descriptive', and 'poignant'

Circle by Jeannie Baker

Written by Jacky Offord · Published Dec 29, 2016

Circle provides a 'stunning', 'meticulously collaged' and 'seamless' account of the godwit's annual migration.

The Ladybird Book of the Meeting, by Jason Hazeley & Joel Morris

Written by Alison Wheeler · Published Dec 24, 2016

Chief executive officer Alison Wheeler recommends The Ladybird Book of the Meeting, by Jason Hazeley & Joel Morris.

The Girl With No Name, by Diney Costeloe

Written by Alice Violett · Published Dec 23, 2016

Web content editor Alice Violett recommends The Girl With No Name, by Diney Costeloe.

Tales of Horror and the Supernatural, by Arthur Machen

Written by Leon Paternoster · Published Dec 22, 2016

Deputy head of IT Leon Paternoster recommends Tales of Horror and the Supernatural, by Arthur Machen.

The Outrun, by Amy Liptrot

Written by Paul Howarth · Published Dec 21, 2016

Stock and content manager Paul Howarth recommends The Outrun, by Amy Liptrot.

The Shepherd's Life: a tale of the Lake District by James Rebanks

Written by Helen Scrivener · Published Dec 20, 2016

Helen is impressed by Rebanks' realistic viewpoint and various talents.

A Place Called Winter, by Patrick Gale

Written by Theo Clarke · Published Dec 20, 2016

Library and information advisor Theo Clarke recommends A Place Called Winter, by Patrick Gale.

The Last of the Spirits, by Chris Priestley

Written by Chris Howard · Published Dec 19, 2016

Lakenheath Library manager Chris Howard recommends The Last of the Spirits, by Chris Priestley.
